node.title: How Peng Shuai Went From ‘Chinese Princess’ to Silenced #MeToo Accuser
node.alt: Peng Shuai during her qualifying match against Nicole Gibbs at U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in New York in 2019.
node.description: The tennis star won independence while remaining in Beijing’s good graces. But she has been unable to break through China’s resistance to sexual assault allegations.
node.content: ["When Peng Shuai was a young tennis player in China\u2019s national sports system, she battled officials for control over her own professional career \u2014 and she won.", "When she took on one of China\u2019s most powerful men three weeks ago, accusing him of sexual assault, she found her voice silenced, erased from China\u2019s heavily controlled cyberspace and smiling in awkward public appearances most likely intended to defuse what has become an international scandal.", "At 35, Ms. Peng is one of her country\u2019s most recognized athletes, a doubles champion at Wimbledon and the French Open whom state media once hailed as \u201cour Chinese princess.\u201d If anyone were able to break through the country\u2019s icy resistance to #MeToo allegations, it would seem to be someone like her.", "Instead, she has become another example of China\u2019s iron grip over politics, society and sports, and an object lesson in the struggle facing women who dare to challenge Beijing \u2014 even those who have had a history of winning praise from the state.", "Her allegation was the first to penetrate the highest pinnacles of power in China, the Politburo Standing Committee. It was an act of courage and perhaps desperation that has resulted in an aggressive response, smothering her inside China.", "\u201cPeng has always been a strong-minded person,\u201d said Terry Rhoads, the managing director of Zou Sports, the talent management agency in Shanghai that represented her for a decade until 2014. \u201cI witnessed up close her struggles and battles with people bossing her or having authority over her tennis.\u201d", "Over the weekend, the state\u2019s propaganda apparatus produced a series of photographs and videos purporting to show Ms. Peng carrying on as if nothing had happened.", "The only thing missing from the recent flurry of coverage was her own voice, one once strong enough to force the authorities to bend to her steely determination to control her own destiny.", "The images were in striking contrast to her own description three weeks ago of being like \u201ca moth darting into the flames\u201d in order to \u201ctell the truth\u201d about her relationship with \u2014 and mistreatment by \u2014 Zhang Gaoli, a former vice premier, who she said assaulted her around three years ago.", "\u201cThe authorities have never liked feminists or #MeToo,\u201d said Lijia Zhang, the author of \u201cLotus,\u201d a novel depicting prostitution in China. Those who \u201cdared to speak out,\u201d she added, \u201chave been silenced.\u201d", "A #WhereisPengShuai campaign has taken root less than three months before Beijing is to host the Winter Olympics, an event that the country\u2019s leadership has indicated would validate Communist Party rule. The handling of Ms. Peng\u2019s accusation has only inflamed criticism, giving ammunition to those who have called for a boycott.", "\u201cThese photos and videos can only prove that Peng Shuai is alive, but nothing else. They cannot prove that Peng Shuai is free,\u201d Teng Biao, one of China\u2019s most prominent civil rights lawyers, said in a telephone call from his home in New Jersey.", "Women in China have long struggled to have agency in the country, a situation that many activists say has worsened since Mr. Xi came to power nearly a decade ago.", "Ms. Peng carved out a professional tennis career that meant taking on officials who tried to dictate whom she could train with, what tournaments she could play in and how much money she could keep for herself.", "When it comes to an accusation of sexual misconduct, however, the state has proved to be more resistant to change. The moment Ms. Peng posted her #MeToo allegations, Mr. Teng said, \u201cshe was barely protected by the law, and it was all politics that determined her fate.\u201d", "Born in the city of Xiangtan, where her father was a police officer, Ms. Peng was introduced to tennis by an uncle when she was 8. At 12, she required surgery to correct a congenital heart defect that left people doubting she could continue to play.", "\u201cThey thought I would leave tennis,\u201d she said in an Adidas ad campaign in 2008, \u201cbut surprisingly, I didn\u2019t give up. Maybe because I love tennis so much I decided to have this operation.\u201d", "After the surgery, she was sent to Tianjin, where she was drafted into China\u2019s Soviet-style sports machine, designed to churn out international competitors, especially in the Olympics. She ultimately competed in the Olympics three times, beginning with Beijing in 2008.", "By the mid-2000s, Ms. Peng decided she was no longer willing to give more than half of her earnings away to the state. She and three other Chinese players decided to break out of the state\u2019s control, effectively by threatening to stop playing.", "When she made the decision in 2005 to \u201cfly solo,\u201d as it was called in Chinese, a sports official criticized her for being too selfish, abandoning her \u201cmother country.\u201d", "\u201cShe thought she was Sharapova?\u201d the official said, referring to the Russian player who was for a time the No. 1 player in women\u2019s tennis.", "Even as she took on decades of sports tradition, Ms. Peng knew how to play to China\u2019s desire to showcase its top athletes. The head coach of the Tianjin Tennis Team, where she had trained, took credit for having \u201ccreated the foundation and conditions for Peng Shuai to fly solo.\u201d", "Ms. Peng later won the doubles championship at Wimbledon in 2013 and again at the French Open in 2014. That year, playing singles, she reached the semifinals of the U.S. Open, peaking as the No. 14 player in the world. With her successes mounting, officials lauded her and other tennis champions, like Li Na, the \u201cgolden flowers\u201d of Chinese sports.", "\u201cShe was very engaging, always smiling and giggling, but also a great competitor,\u201d Patrick McEnroe, the former player and commentator, said in an interview.", "She could also be calculating. In 2018, she was suspended from the Women\u2019s Tennis Association for offering a financial incentive to Alison Van Uytvanck to withdraw as her doubles partner after the deadline for signing up for Wimbledon in 2017. Ms. Van Uytvanck criticized her publicly then, but she has joined other tennis stars in calling for an investigation into the recent allegations.", "A number of women in media, at universities and in the private sector in China have come forward with accusations of sexual assault and harassment \u2014 only to face legal action themselves and harassment online.", "According to the message Ms. Peng posted on Nov. 2 on her verified account on Weibo, the ubiquitous social media platform in China, she first met Mr. Zhang when she was a rising star and he was a party secretary in Tianjin, the provincial-level port city near Beijing. That would have been some time before 2012. She moved to Tianjin to start professional training in 1999 when she was 13.", "Ms. Peng\u2019s post described a conflicted relationship that alternated between playing chess and tennis with Mr. Zhang, or feeling ignored by him and ridiculed by his wife. She did not explicitly acknowledge the disparity in age and power between the two. \u201cRomantic attraction is such a complicated thing,\u201d she wrote.", "Mr. Zhang was elevated to the Politburo Standing Committee in 2012, becoming a vice premier under Mr. Xi. He stepped down after one five-year term on the committee. Ms. Peng said it was around that time that Mr. Zhang coerced her into having sex. \u201cI was crying the entire time,\u201d she wrote.", "Her post was censored within 34 minutes, but three weeks later, it continues to reverberate. Those who knew her from her professional tennis career continue to wonder if she is safe. Some human rights activists contend that she is being forced to take part in staged situations intended to deflect questions about what happened.", "In the flurry of coverage over the weekend, most of which did not appear in Chinese state media, Ms. Peng was shown posing with stuffed animals, dining in a Beijing restaurant, appearing at a youth tournament and dialing in to a video call with the head of the International Olympic Committee.", "\u201cCan any girl fake such a sunny smile under pressure?\u201d Hu Xijin, the editor of The Global Times, a state media tabloid, wrote on Twitter, which is banned in China.", "Ms. Peng no longer appears in control of her own messaging.", "\u201cI wouldn\u2019t be surprised if we see more interviews with Peng Shuai,\u201d Maria Repnikova, an assistant professor of political communication at Georgia State University and author of a new book, \u201cChinese Soft Power, \u201cbut I doubt that she will raise any sensitive matters.\u201d"]
